search_result.title: Hens' Winesett back, just in time for late hockey push
search_result.text:
NEWARK – Meghan Winesett played in all 66 of Delaware’s field hockey games in the 2013, 2014 and 2015 seasons, starting 48.

Missing the first eight this year because of back trouble that required surgery after her sophomore season only means Winesett should be at her best when the Blue Hens play the games that matter most in October and November.

“I’d never missed a game since I started playing the sport,” she said of the initial disappointment from not being on the field this year, “and it was my senior year. I’d been through a lot to get here.

“But I’m glad this year I’m going to be healthy at the end of the season, whereas the previous few years I started to die out.”

Ranked ninth in the National Field Hockey Coaches Association Top 20 poll, the Blue Hens (10-2) have grand ambitions. After making three straight NCAA tournaments, they hope to get past the round-of-16 for the first time in that span, after nearly doing so last year.

Two tests loom less than 24 hours apart this weekend when No. 10-ranked Michigan (7-4) visits Rullo Stadium at 4 p.m. Saturday. The Hens then host CAA rival Hofstra at 1:30 Sunday.

“It’s great to have her back,” Delaware coach Rolf van de Kerkhof said. “We know there’s still another cycle that she has to get back into the swing of things – fine tuning, connecting, synching with her teammates, which she was able to do so well last year. In the games she’s been back you start to see moments where it’s clicking. We just want her to be close to 100 percent when we get to conference tournament play and, hopefully, NCAA play. That was the whole plan from day one.’’

Winesett had been feeling dull pain when, after her freshman season in February of 2014, she injured her back shoveling snow.

“I knew right away something was wrong,” she said, “but also a lot of the pain was in my leg, so never having a back injury before I didn’t think that’s what it was necessarily.’’

Turned out she had a herniated disc.

Physical therapy and cortisone injections provide relief and got Winesett through her sophomore season. The following winter, in early 2015, she had surgery.

“I felt really good after that,” she said. “I played my junior season after my surgery. I didn’t feel 100 percent but I definitely felt better than my sophomore year, before the surgery.”

But when the pain increased last spring, an MRI revealed a re-herniation, which doctors told Winesett is not unusual.

“That was when the question of playing again came in,” said Winesett. “When I went in Doc [Andrew Reisman from UD sports medicine], he asked me ‘Is it worth it?’, chasing a ball around. So that was tough. This whole season, I was unsure how it was going to go. It was another round of PT, cortisone and right now is the best I’ve felt in a really long time.”

Among the therapies Winesett has used is “cupping,” which became widely known during the Summer Olympics because of the purple bruises on swimmer Michael Phelps’ skin.

“It doesn’t feel good when you’re getting it, you’re kind of cringing the whole time,” she said, “but it feels really nice afterward.”

The Chinese technique, in which suction cups are placed against the skin to draw blood from capillaries there, is believed to soothe soreness, speed healing and provide more flexibility by aiding circulation.

“Postgame, I’ve been feeling really, really good,” she said. “I’m more worried about being tired the next day because I’m still trying to get in shape.”

Entering this season, Winesett had scored 26 goals and dealt 17 assists in her UD career, including a school freshman record nine assists in 2013. She had a career-high 10 goals last season.

“She’s a great team player and she keeps it simple,” van de Kerkhof said.

In Sunday’s 3-2 overtime win at William & Mary, Winesett scored her first goal since returning to action this season on Sept. 23 against Albany.

“It was nice to be back on the field and those CAA games are awesome enough without scoring,” Winesett said. “For me, it wasn’t actually getting a goal, it was that’s one thing less to worry about. You can play without that in the back of your head.”

A human services major with a public policy minor, Winesett has also been a National College Honor Society selection. She hopes to work for a non-governmental organization non-profit after she graduates.

Winesett took a unique route to being a scholarship field hockey player. She actually never played on a field hockey team until ninth grade at Westfield High near her Centerville, Virginia, home. She had played roller, in-line and ice hockey, often with her brothers and male cousins, making her quite adept at stick-handling and other relatable skills.

“I got to the point where I wasn’t going to play hockey with all the boys, how can I channel this into something else,” she said, “and I picked up field hockey so easily.”

When recruiting Winesett, van de Kerkhof observed a player who would do “whatever she has to do to put the ball in the goal cage,” he said.

She chose Delaware because van de Kerkhof pitched his vision of Delaware being a national power. Winesett ended up playing a key role in that and is thankful, despite her injury, she should be able to complete her career that way.

“It’s really weird actually seeing it happen,” she said. “You get recruited by all these schools and they tell you what’s going to happen in the future. We were ranked in the 30s as a freshman when I got here and now to see us No. 9, it’s pretty neat to be a part of it. I was more excited to be a part of a growing program rather than one that was already established.”

search_result.title: Delaware inks 6 high school football recruits on NLI signing day
search_result.text:
Six high school class of 2022 football prospects signed a national letter of intent with the University of Delaware Wednesday, but the recruiting process is still well underway for the Blue Hens.

Delaware’s six signees had committed to Delaware when it was coached by Danny Rocco, who was fired Nov. 29. Those commitments were still considered valid by UD and each player had the chance to speak with successor Ryan Carty, the former Blue Hens quarterback whose hiring was announced Dec. 10.

Nine players had originally verbally committed.

“I’d say what impressed me was his responsiveness, attention to detail, wanting to learn about who I am and his commitment to winning and the passion for the university being an alumni,” said Dominic Brogna, the defensive lineman out of Bergen Catholic in northern New Jersey.

A second Signing Day looms Feb. 2 when Delaware could add more recruits. But that isn’t the only avenue to replenish the roster.

Delaware has already lost two players through the transfer portal – linebacker Colby Reeder to Iowa State and kicker Ryan Coe to Cincinnati – with more departures possible. But it’s also a potential place for replacements.

“We will be able to attract whatever needs we have, however we need to do it, in the near future,” Carty told Delawareonline/The News Journal, referring to both the next Signing Day and the transfer portal.

Brogna was joined by Dover High tight end Elijah Sessoms; Thomas Chernasky, another tight end from Western Wayne High in Moscow, Pennsylvania; Isaiah Cherry, a wide receiver/defensive back from John F. Kennedy in Iselin, New Jersey; Steve Dembowksi, an offensive lineman at Pascack Valley in Montvale, New Jersey; and defensive back Gary Seigler from Benedictine in Richmond, Virginia.

Wide receiver/defensive back Shoes Brinkley, the Philadelphian who played this fall at Mater Dei in Santa Ana, California, and had more than a dozen FBS offers, gave Delaware a seventh signee several days l.

“Each member embodies both the quality of player and person that we want to represent Delaware football,” Carty said in a UD press release. “I've been able to connect with each of them and can't wait to get a chance to meet them in person on campus. They are going to be joining at such an exciting and important time in our team’s journey. I'm certain that they will add to our talent and buy into our mentality and vision of this storied program.”

Seigler came away from his discussions with Carty “very pleased at what he had to say,” he said. “We spoke about myself and he got to know me. He seemed like a great person and the type of coach I would trust and play for. He told me that he was ready to get straight to work and I have no doubt that he is the guy for the job.”

Dembowski appreciated Carty’s “high expectations for winning on and off of the field,” he said.

“Knowing that he was a winning Blue Hen,” he added, “wants the same for our current team and values family is also key for me. As an offensive lineman, I am so excited to learn more about the high-energy offense he runs, too.”

Carty came to Delaware after stints as offensive coordinator and quarterbacks coach at New Hampshire and Sam Houston, where his teams often piled up yards and points. UNH reached the FCS semifinals in 2013 and 2014 and Sam Houston was spring 2021 FCS champ.

In discussing his recruiting philosophy during his introductory press conference Monday, Carty said keeping Delaware’s best players at home will be a priority.

“First and foremost, if there is a scholarship level athlete in the state of Delaware, he can’t leave,” Carty said.

Delaware’s recruiting focus will remain in the Mid-Atlantic area, long viewed as a deep reservoir of football talent. It's where his UD coaching predecessors, naturally, drew their rosters from almost entirely.

“I know the national championship team that we had here [in 2003], the teams I had that were successful at New Hampshire and the teams in the CAA that are successful are made up of mostly the guys in this area,” said Carty, a former record-setting quarterback at Somerville High in New Jersey.

But K.C. Keeler, Delaware’s coach from 2002-12, whom Carty played for and served under at Sam Houston, did make Florida and Georgia key recruiting areas as well for Delaware during his stint. And Carty, having also now spent his last four years in Texas, another football hotbed, promised to not limit his scope.

“There are some opportunities in other places for sure,” Carty said. “The beauty of college football now and the beauty of Twitter, social media, is you don’t really have to spend three weeks in a state to go recruit somebody. There’s recruiting services. There’s ways to find people and it’s something you can kind of pick and choose and can still be very, very diligent and detailed in your evaluation process.”

Two Delaware commits who re-opened their recruiting after Rocco’s dismissal ended up at FBS schools. Wide receiver Justin Joly of Iona Prep (New Rochelle, New York) landed at Connecticut and Monroe College linebacker Jalen Stewart, out of Freedom High in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, is bound for Massachusetts.

UConn and UMass are former league rivals of Delaware that moved up to the FBS level but now operate as independents without league affiliation. They were a combined 2-22 this season including UMass’ win over UConn, which scored its victory over Yale.

The Blue Hens’ quest to regain their FCS-level stature is now in the hands of someone who experienced those giddy heights as a player on Delaware’s sixth and most recent national title team.

Carty, who backed up a succession of I-A transfers from 2002-06 at Delaware, has been hired as the Blue Hens’ new football coach, Delaware announced Friday morning.

“I can’t wait to begin our quest towards greatness," Carty said in UD's announcement. "My vision for this program is one that will make Newark and the state of Delaware proud of our success in the classroom, our passion in the community and our relentless pursuit of championships on the football field. My own student-athlete experience at the University of Delaware prepared me for this moment."

Carty will be introduced Monday during a UD press conference. He succeeds Danny Rocco, who was let go after five seasons Nov. 29.

“I definitely think passion for Delaware football is critically important," UD athletic director Chrissi Rawak had said Nov. 30 about prospective coaching candidates, "and the ability for somebody to express that and engage with our fans, our football alumni, is critically important for us.”

The 38-year-old Carty is in his fourth season as offensive coordinator/quarterbacks coach at defending NCAA FCS champ Sam Houston. The top-seeded Bearkats (11-0) host Montana State on Saturday in the FCS quarterfinals after rolling up 556 total yards in a 49-42 second-round win over Incarnate Word.

Carty will remain with Sam Houston through the playoffs. While it was initially expected Carty may retain UD offensive coordinator Jared Ambrose and defensive coordinator Manny Rojas, that is now uncertain.

NOT GOOD ENOUGH: Hens couldn’t meet UD standard under Rocco

Previously, Carty spent 11 seasons at New Hampshire, Delaware’s Colonial Athletic Association rival. Hired by then-Wildcats offensive coordinator Chip Kelly, Carty helped orchestrate what was annually one of the nation’s more imaginative, explosive and diverse offenses. Carty was offensive coordinator and quarterbacks coach his last six seasons there. UNH made the NCAA playoffs each season of Carty’s Durham tenure, including the 2013 and 2014 semifinals.

Carty threw for 3,504 yards and a New Jersey record 43 touchdowns as a Somerville High senior and was in Raymond’s final recruiting class before his February 2002, retirement. That spring, while still in high school, Carty would often attend UD practices trying to get an early education on new coach K.C. Keeler’s no-huddle spread offense.

His Somerville coach was dad Kevin Carty Sr., a well-known New Jersey college and high school coach. Older brothers Kevin Jr., who played quarterback at North Carolina and William & Mary, and Sean, a Rutgers wide receiver, previously starred at Sommerville and are now New Jersey high school coaches.

Carty red-shirted as a UD freshman in 2002 and then was No. 2 behind Andy Hall, Sonny Riccio and Joe Flacco the next four seasons. He received most of his playing time in 2003 backing up Hall for Delaware’s NCAA champions, including throwing his lone career touchdown pass to Joey Bleymaier to close the first-round playoff win over Southern Illinois.

For his career, Carty played in 14 games and rushed for 119 yards and two touchdowns and threw for 192 yards. He was a co-captain as a senior in 2006, when he backed up junior first-year starter Joe Flacco.

"Ryan is clearly an incredible coach," Rawak wrote in a letter to UD fans, " known for his high-octane offense and explosive plays which are only matched by his energy and love for football.

"He has been to two national championship games and won them both. He is incredibly smart, driven and humble. But what separates Ryan as the absolute best choice amongst a terrific group of applicants - was that he is one of us.''

The six seasons Carty directed the New Hampshire attack, it finished every year in the CAA's top five in total offense. Delaware has finished in the top five in CAA total offense just once since 2010, and that was in the 2021 spring season.

“Ryan is as good as an offensive football coach that I’ve been around in my 40 years,” said Sean McDonnell, who recently retired after serving as UNH head coach since 1999, in UD’s announcement. “He’s smart, creative, hardworking and great with the players. He brings an exciting element to the long, storied history of Delaware football.”

At Sam Houston the last four years, Carty's offenses averaged 419.8, 428.0, 440.3 and 490.1 yards per game. Delaware averaged 299.8 this season.

Now he'll be front and center trying to bring the Blue Hens back into the national limelight, but that job will go well beyond X's and O's.

With the indoor Delaware Field House practice facility and recent opening of the Whitney Athletic Center, which has state-of-the-art medical, conditioning and academic support apparatus, the Blue Hens have the proper foundation. Delaware is also annually among the best-funded FCS programs.

Yet, its fortunes have waned.

ROCCO FIRED: Delaware football coach gone 5-6 fall

Delaware reached the NCAA playoffs 20 times in the 38 seasons from 1973-2010, including a Division II title under Raymond in 1979 and the 2003 I-AA (now FCS) championship in 2003 under Keeler, who has been Sam Houston coach since 2014. Delaware also lost NCAA title games in 1974, 1978, 1982, 2007 and 2010 and has had 10 semifinal appearances.

Before that, the Blue Hens won wire-service national titles in 1946 under coach Bill Murray, in 1963 when Dave Nelson was coach and in 1971 and 1972 under Raymond. A back-up quarterback at Michigan during his playing days, Raymond had been Nelson's top offensive assistant for a dozen years before being elevated to the top job.

Murray, Nelson and Raymond are College Football Hall of Famers. Also, the Delaware Wing-T offense, conceived by Nelson and honed by Raymond, became an iconic feature of the Hens’ success that spread to all levels of football.

But Delaware has reached the postseason just twice since 2010, in 2018 and the spring of 2021. Delaware went 7-1 and made the FCS semifinals in the spring.

However, a 5-6 finish this fall, the second losing record in three years, led to Rocco’s dismissal after five seasons. Under Rocco, Delaware was 31-23 overall and 20-16 in CAA games.

Delaware has also seen its attendance plummet. Home crowds averaged 12,844 in the fall of 2021, Delaware’s lowest since 1968 (10,810) and nearly 10,000 below the record 22,280 in 2004. Rawak has said winning regularly is the first step toward changing that.

Signing day for high school Class of 2022 recruits is Dec. 15, adding to the urgency in getting a new coach in place. Rocco and his staff received verbal commitments from nine prospects but one has already chosen a different school and another has de-committed.

"I feel like he’s going to be a good fit for the program and I feel like he will get the program back to being a winning program," said incoming tight end Elijah Sessoms of Dover High on Friday.

There has also been a parade to the transfer portal, where Blue Hens such as linebacker Colby Reeder, quarterback Nolan Henderson, wide receiver Thyrick Pitts, safety Noah Plack and linebacker Johnny Buchanan put their names to see what other opportunities exist. Carty actually recruited and offered Henderson a scholarship when he was coaching at UNH.

All have quickly received a succession of notable offers. Delaware has already lost kicker Ryan Coe to Cincinnati. Reeder, the Salesianum School graduate, is reportedly closely eyeing Rutgers, Iowa State and Kansas State.

Rawak had said the new coach needed to be “someone that really understands the traditions of football [at Delaware] and understands what we have here, the talent we have here and is able to really maximize that talent.” Rawak had also suggested that coaches with proven offensive backgrounds may be particularly suitable.

All that made Carty a leading candidate, despite his lack of head coaching experience. There was considerable fanfare to bring back Keeler, who was fired as Delaware coach in January 2013, and remains a popular figure, especially with Delaware's lack of success since. Any effort to do that, however, was nixed by influential UD leadership, Delawareonline/The News Journal learned.

Oddly, neither the letter to UD fans nor the press announcement said Carty served under former UD coach Keeler at Sam Houston.

Nonetheless, Carty's selection will appeal to many UD fans and former players.

"Ryan is a tireless worker, tremendous teacher and dedicated student of the game," Bleymaier, now the Kansas City Chiefs wide receivers coach, said in the UD press release. "He’s demonstrated unparalleled X’s and O’s acumen, yet also combines a rare ability to see the big picture without missing a single detail.''

Michael Jackson is an electrical engineering major with a 3.4 grade-point average at Virginia Military Institute, from which he’ll graduate in May.

Jackson will attend Delaware beginning this summer as a graduate transfer seeking a master’s degree in business administration while also completing his college football career.

The 6-foot-2, 185-pound wide receiver announced Saturday on Twitter he’d chosen Delaware over a bevy of opportunities. UD made his intentions official on Wednesday, the second national letter of intent signing day for incoming recruits.

Delaware also announced incoming transfer wide receiver Jalyn Witcher, an FCS All-American as a freshman in 2021 at Presbyterian, and the addition of graduate punter Ben Dinkel from South Dakota State, where he had a 61-yard boot in the Jackrabbits’ 33-3 win over Delaware in the spring FCS semifinals.

Delaware still has scholarship offers out to other potential transfers, including several offensive linemen, and high school recruits who have not yet settled on a destination.

“We are actively trying to add value and talent to this roster at all times, all season long,” Carty said. “ … We are not gonna stop recruiting.”

That December group of recruits is made up of cornerback Shuyab “Shoes” Brinkley, a Philadelphian who attended Mater Dei in Santa Ana, California, as a senior; defensive lineman Dominick Brogna from Bergen Catholic and Bayville, New Jersey; tight end Thomas Chernasky of Western Wayne in Moscow, Pennsylvania; wide receiver Isaiah Cherry from John F. Kennedy and Woodbridge, New Jersey; offensive lineman Steve Dembowksi from Pascack Valley and Montvale, New Jersey; defensive back Gary Seigler from Benedictine College Prep in Richmond, Virginia; and tight end Elijah Sessoms out of Dover High.

None of those seven are graduating from high school early so they’ll arrive at Delaware in the summer.

Jackson caught 102 passes for 1,210 yards and nine touchdowns in four seasons for the Keydets, who were spring 2021 Southern Conference champions. “I believe in my ability every time I touch the field, so … I was a starter the two previous years as well and I just try to help the team any way I can.”

search_result.title: Former Buckley's Tavern operator opening new Goat Kitchen & Bar
search_result.text:
Patricia Talorico

The News Journal

The newly stained cement floor looks like a wet, shiny puddle and Dave Weir is a little worried how he will keep it looking so clean and polished once customers begin walking through the front door

It's just another item to add to the list of things to do before the former Buckley's Tavern operator opens his own restaurant next month in Brandywine Hundred.

Weir hopes to start serving food and drinks on Feb. 1 at Goat Kitchen & Bar in the Plaza III shopping center.

But, he says the 82-seat new American restaurant at 1845 Marsh Road - the former home of China Royal, a Chinese eatery that operated for 24 years - could just quietly open its doors one day with little fanfare.

Lunch and dinner will be served daily, and Sunday brunch is part of the plan. He says the vibe will be laid back, casual, family-friendly and affordable.

"I want it to be like the feel of the tavern area at Buckley's," says Weir who for 22 years ran the Centreville institution at 5812 Kennett Pike, which many consider one of the best loved bars in Delaware.

He also was involved in the partnership that ran Four Dogs Tavern, Chadds Ford Inn and the Marshalton Inn, all in Pennsylvania.

In December 2011, Weir told The News Journal the owners of Buckley's Tavern decided not to renew his lease. Weir held his last pajama Sunday brunch on Jan. 15, 2012 - he founded the popular discounted meal - and a line snaked around the parking lot.

The Centreville restaurant, now with new operators, has been completely renovated. It reopened in October 2013.

After departing Buckley's, Weir wasn't sure where his career was headed. Warren T. Scott, his friend and the restaurant partner he worked with at Four Dogs Tavern and its adjoining Marshalton Inn, died in October 2012.

Weir decided to try his hand at restaurant consulting, but found it wasn't profitable. He took a job at Georgetown, Maryland's Kitty Knight House, and then stayed at home for six months with his 3 1/2 year-old twins.

But, the 53-year-old always knew he wanted to come back to Delaware and own his own business. The Delaware restaurant industry is one that Weir knows well having worked in businesses as far back as his days of bartending and managing the old Oscar's in downtown Wilmington (it's now Cavanaugh's Restaurant).

A bartender absorbs much more than customers might imagine and Weir jokes that he still sees former patrons and remembers their orders - and actions.

"I'll be like, there's 'Gin-and-tonic,' there's 'Beer Guy,' there's 'the one who could never get anywhere with the redhead.'"

Weir, who has an investor, began searching for locations in 2014. He passed on a building in Wilmington's Trolley Square neighborhood and rejected a Hockessin site because of its lack of parking.

In August, he found what he was looking for in north Wilmington. His daughter had worked at The Comic Book Shop in the Plaza III Center owned by Capano Management Company, and mentioned the vacant China Royal site was available.

The Chinese restaurant, which opened in 1989, had been popular for more than two decades, but began losing its luster in its waning years. It closed in 2013 when the owner retired.

Since September, Weir has been working on the interior. For years, he has been scribbling down design ideas in a notebook and had a vision for what he wanted.

He stripped away the outdated and shabby decor and ripped up the former rug. The cement floor has since been stained black and sealed with a glossy polyurethane. The kitchen was renovated as well as the restrooms.

The bar is the same one China Royal used, but Weir added a new top and wood reclaimed from a 1997 fire at the Marshalton Inn.

Rustic, "shabby chic" reclaimed doors from a Reading, Pennsylvania, salvage shop decorate one of the dining room's walls. Doors to the restrooms come from old hotel rooms - and still have numbers on them. A former church pew rests against a wall. "Being a Catholic altar boy, I still feel the guilt," Weir jokes.

And while Weir left Buckley's behind three years ago, Buckley's apparently hasn't left him.

Goat's menu has Thai chicken noodle soup - just like Buckley's - but Weir says it's not the same recipe. He also has plans to offer pizzas and burgers as he did at Buckley's.

But there are new offerings. Noshes include nachos with crab salsa; lemon and Parmesan potato chips; and thyme-baked honey feta with flatbread.

A roasted pork meatball bánh mi and a spiced lamb wrap with Brie and curried mustard are among the sandwiches. The short list of changing entrees includes porter braised short ribs and shrimp, tasso ham and grits.

Weir says since his wife and daughter both follow a plant-based diet, he will have more vegetarian offerings. Seitan or tofu can replace any meat.

At the 14-seat bar, Weir will offer eight craft beers on tap and plans to charge $8 for all glasses of wine.

Surprisingly, for a restaurant named Goat there is little of it on the menu save for goat cheese toasts.

Weir says the name doesn't have much meaning other than it's one he liked. He hopes to follow Goat with other places such as Pig, a takeout shop focusing on pork, and Rabbit, which would be mostly vegetarian.

The owner of the 4-year-old Goat Kitchen & Bar has closed the Brandywine Hundred restaurant permanently and said there is "an ongoing legal investigation."

A post Tuesday evening on the Goat Kitchen & Bar's Facebook page announced the closing.

Due to extremely unfortunate circumstances, Goat has closed its doors. I hope to many of our long-time customers, you remember Goat as how it began and not how it ended. To quote one of Dave Weir's favorite authors: "Some people are more forgiving when they understand a situation, while others become even more furious once they see the whole picture."

- Jonathan Carroll

Dave Weir began making plans for Goat a few years after he left Buckley's in 2011 when the building's owners decided not to renew his lease.

He later took over the site of the former China Royal, a Chinese eatery that operated for 24 years, and transformed it into Goat Kitchen & Bar.

Chancery Market Food Hall & Bar, a new dining destination opening this fall in downtown Wilmington, has announced that a fried chicken concept from celebrity chef David Chang will be one of the vendors at the site that's still under construction.

The 12,000-square-foot culinary collective at the 12-story building at 1313 N. Market St., known as Hercules Plaza when it opened in 1984, also has lined up a Wilmington vegan vendor, and another operator will sell Indian street foods served on flatbreads and in rice bowls.

This is a second food hall for Wilmington. DECO, a 13,000-square-foot food hall with eight food stalls at 111 W. 10th St., has been operating since April 2019. It was developed by the Buccini/Pollin Group and is just blocks away from Chancery Market.

The 1313 N. Market St. building and a nearby 23-story site being redeveloped at 1201 N. Market St., the tallest building in the city, are owned by TSG Hospitality LLC. Both buildings house several prominent law firms, including Potter Anderson & Corroon, one of the oldest and largest in Delaware; Saul Ewing Arnstein & Lehr; and Morris, Nichols, Arsht & Tunnell.

HQ Hospitality, a Brooklyn-based culinary consulting and food hall management firm led by chef, restaurateur, cookbook author and co-founder Akhtar Nawab, is overseeing the management of the market and food hall.

What is Fuku?

So far, the best-known vendor at Chancery Market will be Fuku, a fried chicken venture from chef, author and TV star David Chang, known for founding the Momofuku restaurant empire which has restaurants in New York, Los Angeles, Las Vegas and Toronto. Chang also has starred in such culinary-based TV shows as "Ugly Delicious" on Netflix and "The Mind of a Chef" on PBS. He also hosts a podcast, "The David Chang Show."

Some Philadelphia Eagles fans may be familiar with Fuku's spicy fried chicken sandwich, a habanero-brined thigh served on a Martin’s potato roll and garnished with pickles and mayo. It was first available at Eagles games at Lincoln Financial Field in 2018, but Fuku is not listed as one of the concessions this year at the Philadelphia stadium.

What started out as a "secret sandwich" at Chang's Momofuku Noodle Bar in New York grew into a fast-casual food business.

Fuku offers chicken sandwiches, along with salads, sides and slushies, at shops in New York, California, Georgia, Kentucky and Texas and stadiums from Washington, D.C., to Seattle.

A Fuku shop that had opened on Spring Garden Street in Philadelphia is no longer operating.

What else is coming to Chancery Market Food Hall & Bar?

In addition to Fuku, Nawab said another new business at Chancery Market is Rooted AF, a quick-service vegan experience from the owners of Wilmington's The Juice Joint. It will sell "multicultural fare," herbal products, fresh cold-pressed juices and smoothies.

And a third confirmed business is KatiRoll Wala, which serves Indian street food staples at a food hall in Knoxville, Tennessee.

Relocating:Rosenfeld's Deli closes Wilmington site, focuses on Brandywine Hundred location

Kati rolls, food originating from Kolkata, West Bengal, India, include grilled chicken thighs, farmer's cheese or chickpeas, potatoes and cauliflower wrapped in a paratha, an Indian flatbread, along with sliced onions and sauces, like cilantro or butter masala. The stand also will sell a variety of rice bowls.

Nawab said he is still looking for more concepts and encourages vendor applications from minority-owned businesses and chefs who enjoy delving into global cuisine and exploring other creative foods.

“Our goal is for our kitchens to serve as a springboard for talented, local vendors looking to take their businesses to the next level and to create a thriving, communal space where visitors feel welcome," Nawab said in a prepared statement.

What days will the food hall be open?

Plans call for Chancery Market, Food Hall & Bar to be open daily.

The site also will feature the indoor/outdoor Nectar Bar, along with public and private dining spaces and seating for 233 people. Onsite garage parking will be available.

search_result.title: World Cafe Live leaves the Queen; new managers expected
search_result.text:
World Cafe Live is leaving the Queen Theater and new management is headed in, keeping it as a live music venue and "community clubhouse."

The music venue – World Cafe Live at the Queen – will close its doors on May 25 after a six-year run, according to an announcement by Hal Real, president of World Cafe Live and Real Entertainment Group.

Chris Buccini, co-president of the Buccini/Pollin Group, which redeveloped the historic theater, said the live event space will simply be known as the Queen starting May 26.

Tuesday night, Buccini said he could not name what entertainment company will take over the 45,000-square-foot theater because the deal was still being finalized.

"Shortly, in the next few weeks, we will be making the announcement about who we're partnering up with for the operation of it," he said.

Buccini stressed that the theater will continue to host a mix of national and local acts and will continue to be an event space for weddings and private parties.

"We want to make sure that everything the Queen has meant to people in the past continues in the future, and we have to button up those details," he said, adding that both the upstairs and downstairs stages will remain. "Everything, whether it's the big act, the small local act or the Light Up the Queen Foundation programs – the goal is to actually only get more of that there."

He expects the Queen will close for a couple of weeks in the summer for a minor renovation, which includes an enhancement of the upstairs stage.

Real broke the news that World Cafe Live will be pulling out of Wilmington in an email to his team late Monday night.

"When I think about how lower Market Street looked and felt 10 years ago versus today, it’s hard to believe it’s the same place," Real wrote. "However, even though lots has improved physically on much of Market Street, the revitalization has just not been strong enough and fast enough to support our robust 7-day/week WCL model. So, while I’m certainly no quitter, you really do have to 'know when to fold.'”

To celebrate the venue's role as a clubhouse for the local music community, Real said in a statement there will be a final show – free of charge – on May 25 featuring "performances by many of the Brandywine Valley’s most cherished groups and performers."

Through a representative, Real declined to be interviewed.

Bill Dougherty, the Queen's food and beverage manager, learned of World Cafe Live's departure in a manager's meeting on Monday at 5 p.m.

Real had gathered about 10 members of his top staff and broke the news to them.

"We were stunned," Dougherty said. "[Real] is heartbroken. This was his baby. I'm sure he would much rather have had a different meeting. There were tears."

News Journal Archive: The Queen prepares to open

Steve Szymanski, a 53-year-old Queen patron, said he has relatives in their 90s who attended silent movie screenings at the Queen years ago. The banking professional said he will miss its latest incarnation with its cheap nearby parking, beer selection, variety of music and friendly staff.

"It'll be a big loss," he said, but added that he will continue to visit under new management. "If they have the money to support [live music] in Wilmington, which is crucial to the survival of the city … I would support them."

Dougherty estimates World Cafe Live at the Queen has about 100 full- and part-time employees. They were informed via email Tuesday morning, he said.

Real told The News Journal in 2011 that he was determined to make the project work. "Failure for us would be a really sad state of affairs for Market Street," he said.

The Queen Theater was originally built in the 1800s, converted to a vaudeville theater in the 1920s and was a movie house before closing in 1959.

It had been left for dead for nearly 50 years before Buccini/Pollin Group renovated the theater at Fifth and Market streets. A ribbon-cutting ceremony and the first concert were held there on April 1, 2011.

Joe Trainor performed on the World Cafe Live stage on May 30 of that year for a soft opening. That first show would be one of many for the pianist and singer, who has performed with his namesake band Joe Trainor Trio, the tribute band In the Light and as an act for the venue's annual fundraiser, Shine a Light. A main draw for Trainor was the staff's attitude toward local artists.

"When you're a musician, part of the reason you get into it is because you want that kind of atmosphere. And when they treat you like a rock star, you're going to want to go back," he said.

Trainor said the idea of corporate management makes him "apprehensive."

"I love this city. If a vendor can come in and make the venue more successful, then it's good for the city," he said. "As a musician, if it's not open to our art scene, it could be a detriment. I’m on both sides of the fence."

Tina Betz, executive director of the Light Up the Queen Foundation, echoed Buccini and said the foundation's work to promote arts awareness and arts programs will continue.

"Within all of the discussions about the new management coming in, what the Light Up the Queen Foundation does has been an important part of it," she said. "And it needed to be guaranteed that we would still have our comfortable fit in our home."

In Real's email, he thanked staff and performers for "being part of such an ambitious and exhilarating effort."

With two stages and capacity to host 950 people, the public/private $25 million rehabilitation of the long-forgotten Queen ushered in a new era of music for Wilmington, pumping more national and local acts onto Market Street than ever before.

From high school bands playing some of their first gigs to well-known acts like Dr. John, Lake Street Dive, Chris Stapleton, Neutral Milk Hotel, The xx and Ingrid Michaelson, World Cafe Live at the Queen became what Real dreamed, telling The News Journal in 2009 that Delawareans could "expect we will use all our resources to create a new Wilmington clubhouse for the music and arts community."

Gayle Dillman, whose Gable Music Ventures has booked more than 200 shows there since 2012, lamented the loss of one of the only music rooms in the state where underage acts could perform and grow.

"This is how Gable started – as a platform for underage bands – original music for all ages," said Dillman, who is now hunting for a new venue for her weekly "Wilmo Wednesday" variety show, which drew 50 to 100 people each week. "And while [Wilmington rock clubs] Oddity Bar and 1984 are great, the kids can't go in there. This means there's a new challenge for us, and we'll figure it out."

Andrea Sikora and her husband, Bryan, own and run three city restaurants – La Fia Market Bistro, Merchant Bar and Cocina Lolo Mexican Restaurant – all within one block of the Queen. She said the couple hasn’t seen much business from the concert venue, before or after a show, in recent years, particularly in the last year and a half.

“We got the sense the energy was lower [at The Queen]," she said. "In 2014, we were observing large crowds, the corner was bopping and La Fia was busy on show nights. But we haven’t felt that energy in a long while.”

She said she believes the last big spillover crowd at their restaurants was when local musician Ben LeRoy and his band The Snap played a reunion show at the venue in November.

“He brought the crowds,” Sikora said. “I can’t think of any other show like that since then.”

Sikora said she’s hoping a new operator at the Queen will bring “a new vision.”

“We’re optimistic. We would be happy to see a new operator bring back the energy of 2014,” Sikora said. “We’re supportive of any new ownership coming in and we can all work together.”

Besides concerts, the Queen has also hosted other events like weddings, TEDx Wilmington events and the MidAtlantic Wine + Food Festival. Buccini/Pollin hosted the premiere of a local music video there in November. And Hillary Clinton held a rally there in April ahead of Delaware's primary election.

Even before construction began at the Queen, it had an uphill climb. The deal for the new venue was made with a handshake in 2007, just before the global economic meltdown.

"Wilmington is just now, economically and renaissance-wise, about where we hoped it would be when we opened five years ago," Real told The News Journal ahead of the Queen's fifth anniversary last year. "I think we're real close to the tipping point now."

The cash to fund the venue's $25 million renovation came from public and private sources. Tax credits yielded about $11 million, and the city gave $3 million, The News Journal reported in 2011. The other half came from a combination of foundation grants, state funds, corporate donations and individual contributions.

Mark Fields, executive director of the Grand, only three blocks from the Queen, said the city and its residents have invested too much money into the Queen to let it fail.

"I trust our leadership and community to do what's in the best interest of the community to make sure this doesn't become a setback," he said.

Faced with increased competition and a changing music industry, Fields said running a concert venue has become a "brutal business." He said World Cafe Live's ambition to be open every day likely made things difficult.

World Cafe Live in Philadelphia will continue to operate, Real wrote, and the company also plans to launch an initiative called "World Cafe Live Presents" which hopes to present World Cafe Live concerts and events at other venues in and outside the region.

The Market Street location will host events through the end of May including singer-songwriter KT Tunstall and the annual Shine a Light concert fundraiser, which benefits the Light Up the Queen Foundation.

Buccini praised Real for his role in resurrecting the theater in the heart of Wilmington's downtown, which came just after the worldwide economic downturn of 2008.



"If it wasn't for Hal Real, the Queen would not exist today," he said. "He wasn't from here. It had been vacant for half a century. And he really was the catalyst. Things didn't work out exactly as we would have hoped, but I think he really left his mark on our community."

search_result.title: Jay Caputo out at Rehoboth Beach's Beachside Bar and Grill
search_result.text:
Patricia Talorico

The News Journal

Sussex County chef Jay Caputo is no longer involved with Beachside Bar and Grill, a Rehoboth Beach eatery on the resort town's main thoroughfare.

Caputo sold his interest in the 251 Rehoboth Ave. eatery he ran for the past year with David M. Dietz, owner of Greenville's BBC Tavern and Grill, according to a press release sent Friday. The amount was not disclosed.

Caputo said he is concentrating on Pilot Town Fish Co., a new Milton restaurant off Del. 1 in the Paynters Mill Center.

"I accomplished what I intended to do at Beachside, which was to create a funky little beach restaurant with an eclectic menu that would appeal to the locals year-round," said Caputo in the prepared statement. He still owns Espuma, a Rehoboth restaurant on Wilmington Avenue and First Street.

The new operator and part-owner of Beachside is John Wallden. He has an interest in Shorebreak Restaurant at 10 Wilmington Ave., which he is selling to business partners Matt Sprenkle and Rob Stitt. Terms of the deal are private.

REVIEW: Hotel du Pont's Green Room still an elegant lady

MAILBAG: Moro restaurant still going strong, owner says

Wallden plans to keep some menu items at Beachside, and will be adding lobster and shrimp rolls, steamed clams and mussels, pulled pork sandwiches and fish tacos. There will be a new wine list and different cocktails.

Caputo and Dietz opened Beachside in July 2015. The partners had worked a year on the project to create the 114-seat casual eatery, formerly a shoe store specializing in running. The site had been a gas station up until the 1960s.

Dietz was handling the business side of the operation, while Caputo, who has received several James Beard semifinalist award nominations for Best Chef: MidAtlantic, was in charge of the culinary end.

Beachside is Dietz's first Sussex County venture. He has run the BBC Tavern and Grill on Kennett Pike since September 2009. Previously, he owned the Brandywine Brewing Co. (now the site of Pizza by Elizabeths).

Caputo, known for his fine-dining meals at Espuma, has branched out over the years and has offered more casual fare. He formerly ran The Rose & Crown in Lewes, and had owned the former Cabo Modern Mexican Tequila Bar in Rehoboth, before selling it to SoDel Concepts. The 210 Second St. restaurant is now home to Papa Grande's Coastal Taqueria.

search_result.title: Red Clay School District elects new superintendent
search_result.text:
Dorrell Green has been selected as the next superintendent for the largest school district in Delaware.

The Red Clay school board voted on Wednesday night to start negotiating a contract with Green, now the former director of the Office of Innovation and Improvement for the Delaware Department of Education.

The administrative position oversees a district with more than 17,000 students.

Green said he was honored and humbled by the board's decision.

"I'm elated," he said. "I'm thankful for the opportunity to be selected as a new leader for the Red Clay District, which is my home and where my children attend school."

Green beat out the current deputy superintendent at the district, Hugh Broomall. The two went toe to toe in a public forum on Monday night, responding to questions on how they would best serve the district.

With 19-years of experience, Green began as an elementary school teacher at Christina School District schools. He then moved to Brandywine School District, where he was the assistant superintendent and handled operations. In 2017, he headed the first Office of Innovation and Improvement, a program to support struggling schools in Wilmington.

Green received five of the seven board member votes. Parents, administrators and community activists attended Wednesday's meeting to lobby for candidates and await the results.

"You need to come to a decision that will lead to the best Red Clay District," director of Wilmington nonprofit, FAME, Don Baker told the board.

One parent pointed at test scores. In state tests, Red Clay has scored 51 percent proficiency in reading, and in math, it was 38 percent. She said the district needed a shift in leadership, and recommended Green for the job.

"We need something different," Marsha Carter said to the board.

Background:Red Clay School District to vote on new superintendent Wednesday night

The district spent months narrowing down a list of candidates for the job, including two rounds of interviews, many executive sessions and public discussion.

The predecessor Merv Daughtery left the $178,000 position for a job in Virginia, leaving Chief Financial Officer Jill Floore as the interim superintendent.

Green said after the discussion at the board meeting, healing needs to happen.

Board members also argued about the approach to renew Charter School of Wilmington's charter.

Some wanted the school to respond to a list of questions tackling diversity in the charter, while others said the tactic was too abrasive and not needed.

"It's ultimately what are we going to come and do," he said. "Hopefully I can be that conduit, to be that change everyone is seeking and bridge that divide."

search_result.title: Christina finalizes contract with new superintendent
search_result.text:
Christina School District finalized a contract with its new superintendent Tuesday, clearing the way for him to take the reins on April 18.

Richard L. Gregg, formerly assistant superintendent of the Penn-Delco School District in Aston, Pennsylvania, will be paid $180,000, with an increase of 2.25 percent a year.

His contract is for a little over a year, through June 2018, and he will receive state benefits and a $400 monthly vehicle allowance.

Gregg was chosen for the position in January, beating out Sam Golder, director of secondary school operations in the Red Clay Consolidated School District, and Jerry Wilson, who most recently was superintendent of Worcester County Public Schools in Newark, Maryland.

Though Gregg has worked in Pennsylvania since last year, his roots are in Christina, he has said, the district in which he was educated, where he’s previously served as a teacher and to which he sent his kids.

“I’m a product of this district, and I’m proud to be a product of this district," Gregg said in January. “I believe I can give something back. There’s a vested interest in the success of the schools in this district.”

STORY: Christina superintendent finalists make their cases

STORY: Three superintendent finalists named for Christina School District

As assistant superintendent in Aston, Gregg has been responsible for district-wide curriculum and instruction, assessment, special education, professional development and technology integration. He also oversaw the district budget and supervised administrative staff.

Previously, he served as principal of Penncrest High School in Media, Pennsylvania, and as director of instruction for New Castle County Vocational Technical School District in Delaware. He has also served as principal of Brandywine High School, and principal and assistant principal of Concord High School in the Brandywine School District. In the Christina School District, he once served as assistant principal at Christiana High School.

Gregg's teaching experience includes a total of nine years’ experience as a high school social studies teacher. He holds a bachelor’s degree in history from the University of Delaware and a master’s degree in school leadership and instruction from Wilmington University. He is a graduate of Glasgow High School.

Having studied the district’s strategic plan, Gregg during his interview said the goals he’s most interested in achieving by June are dealing with school safety through setting clear expectations for their culture; continuing to pursue honors and dual enrollment programs; and improving retention of students, especially as they enter high school.

The board vote was 5-2 in Gregg’s favor thanks to Fredrick Polaski’s last-second switch from supporting Golder. Golder already had lost the vote after Board President Elizabeth Campbell Paige cast her tie-breaking final vote, and Polaski said his switch was meant to show solidarity.

Christina’s previous superintendent, Freeman Williams, left the district in 2015 for medical reasons and Robert Andrzejewski served as acting superintendent until Dec. 31, when Noreen LaSorsa took his place as interim administrator.

search_result.title: Hunterdon Central names interim superintendent
search_result.text:
FLEMINGTON - Manville's retired superintendent of schools will serve as the interim superintendent of the Hunterdon Central school district beginning July 1.





Johanna Ruberto was appointed Monday by the Hunterdon Central school board to head the school district for $605 a day until a successor is named for Christina Steffner, who resigned in March to become superintendent in Livingston.



READ: Hunterdon Central superintendent leaving for Livingston



READ: Hunterdon Central teacher claims she was fired because she is Muslim​



Ruberto, who has a doctorate in education from Seton Hall University, retired as Manville superintendent in 2014. She had previously been assistant superintendent in Rockaway and Berkeley Heights and a principal in Readington, Franklin (Somerset) and Bound Brook.



She was named superintendent of the year in Somerset County in 2014. Recently, she had been serving as interim superintendent in South Plainfield.



In recent years, as the turnover in school superintendents increased because of the salary cap imposed by the state, it has become a common practice for districts to hire retired administrators to serve as interim superintendents.



School officials say that a typical search for a new superintendent takes about nine months.



The process involves seeking community input on what qualifications, experience and skills the new superintendent should have and how the candidate will fit into Hunterdon Central's culture.



Interviews with finalists for the Hunterdon Central post are not anticipated to be held until the end of 2016.



An interim superintendent may serve for as long as two years.



School board President Deb Labbadia said the board was "impressed" with Ruberto's background, her community outreach efforts and her strategic curriculum planning.



Board Vice President Kathy Raborn said the board is committed to "ensuring a smooth and positive transition."



Raborn also said the pool of qualified applicants is limited, "but we're not discouraged."



"People want to work here," she said.



Like many other school districts throughout New Jersey, Hunterdon Central is seeking a consultant to help with the search process.



The community will be involved in every step during the process, including open meetings with constituent groups, the creation of ad hoc committees, surveys and focus groups.



Hunterdon Central has close to 3,000 students, with a $68 million budget.

search_result.title: Columbus Board of Education talks new bus routes, thanks Dixon
search_result.text:
Columbus City Schools Board of Education members discussed solutions to the district's ongoing busing issues, praised retiring Superintendent Talisa Dixon and officially appointed Dixon's interim successor at its final board meeting of the year.

Rodney Stufflebean, the district's interim director of transportation, shared with the board that the district will be ready to roll out new bus routes in the new year.

"Everything is still on track," Stufflebean said.

Columbus City Schools, plagued by busing route issues this fall using the AlphaRoute software, now also used VersaTrans software by Tyler Technologies, which the district previously used, to prepare new bus routes that will go into effect after winter break.

The district is in a three-year contract with AlphaRoute and spent more than $1.5 million on that software, according to a May school board agenda. The district’s contract with Versatrans, which cost $95,815, started on Nov. 1 and expires on June 6.

The new VersaTrans bus routes were completed Nov. 15 and the Ohio Association of Public School Employees rebid bus drivers' contracts earlier this month. Bus drivers have been doing dry runs of their new routes since Dec. 5.

There are currently 506 drivers ready to begin in the new year, Stufflebean said. He added that having more drivers than current routes will be a good extra layer of security in case issues arise.

Scott Varner, Columbus City Schools executive director of family and student engagement, said the district has tried to overcommunicate with students and parents over the last six weeks in preparation for these changes. Between mailers, phone calls, fliers sent home with students, emails, social media posts and one-on-one conversations, parents received route-specific information at least six times, Stufflebean said.

For those with lingering questions, the district's Transportation Call Center will be staffed from 6 a.m. to 4 p.m. over winter break weekdays (except federal holidays) in case parents have questions about their child's route. Additional staff members will also be manning phones during the first week classes resume.

Saying goodbye to Dixon, James

After an hourlong executive session at the beginning of Tuesday's meeting, Columbus City School Board President Jennifer Adair and the rest of the board recognized Dixon and Deputy Superintendent of Operations David James for their work in the district.

James announced in late November that he would be leaving the Columbus district to be the new executive director of the Summit Education Institute in Akron. His last day working in the district is Dec. 31. James came to Columbus in June 2021 after retiring from Akron City Schools after 30 years, including 13 as superintendent.

Tuesday's board meeting was Dixon's first since she announced her intentions to retire as superintendent at the end of this academic year.

Board member Christina Vera, who attended the now-closed Brookhaven High School when Dixon was principal in the early 2000s, reflected on their time together, first as teacher-student and now as peers.

"It's truly a fill-circle experience to not only learn from you but also serve alongside you," she said.

To both James and Dixon, board member Tina Pierce said she has been grateful for their leadership and commitment to asking difficult questions.

"May you continue to challenge those around you to be great," Pierce said.

Board officially appoints Angela Chapman as interim superintendent

The board also approved the contract for Angela Chapman, Columbus City Schools interim superintendent.

Chapman, who was brought into the administration by Dixon in 2019, has been the chief transformation and leadership officer for the district. Chapman will begin as interim superintendent on Jan. 1.

Dixon will remain on as an Educational Administrator to support and assist with the transition of leadership for the remainder of the school year, the district said earlier this month.

According to her contract, Chapman's daily per diem salary shall be increased by $300 as interim superintendent. She currently earns $157,874.68 a year.

The board did not discuss or give any new information about when and how the search for a permanent superintendent will take place.

search_result.title: Christina embarks on massive turnaround to help Wilmington students
search_result.text:
One of the lowest-performing school districts in the state says it will compete to attract more of the area's best students.

When new Superintendent Richard Gregg was a student in the district in the 1970s, Christina was not only the biggest school district in the state, it had some of the best test scores.

Today, Christina has firmly established itself as one of the lowest-performing school districts, with less than 50 percent of third-graders proficient in either reading or math.

Over the past seven years, the district's enrollment has declined by more than 2,000 students, or 12 percent, Department of Education data shows. In comparison, enrollment at Red Clay and Brandywine is higher today than it was in 2010. Both of those districts have seen fluctuations over the years, but not nearly as dramatic as Christina.

Gregg wants to focus attention on improving the education of its Wilmington students. And he's ready to undertake a massive overhaul of how the district educates and operates to do it.

The plan will also put a major emphasis on keeping students from leaving the district for charter and magnet schools and improving the district's reputation.

As it stands today, parents are choosing to send their students to other schools and voting against referendums that could help Christina offer more competitive programming and support to students.

"I think that people have been waiting for this for a long time," Gregg said. "And I don't think we have time to wait.

"I don't think it's a creative direction, necessarily. I think it's a direction born out of need."

Christina is home to three of the state's priority schools, those with the lowest test scores in Delaware. They have been singled out by the state for needing immediate improvement. At Bayard Middle, only 3 percent of students are proficient in math and a mere 8 percent are proficient in English.

The Wilmington Education Improvement Commission, a state advisory committee formed to come up with ideas to improve education in the city, has suggested that Christina's Wilmington-based schools be taken away from the district and given to Red Clay. They feel the district is incapable of meeting the needs of both suburban and urban students.

It also recommended extra resources for schools with a high percentage of students who live in poverty.

But two years in a row, the state legislature was not able to implement any of the recommendations.

STORY:Joe Biden, business leaders talk future U.S. labor force during panel discussion

STORY:Carrie Downie boys learn to run, talk about their feelings

Gregg, who has been superintendent since April 18, is not waiting. He wants to begin implementing new programming and reworking the district's city schools by next September.

At Bayard, for instance, the district has already introduced an alternative-to-suspension program that keeps kids in school instead of sending them home. Repetitive out-of-school suspensions are known to have a negative impact on student learning and growth.

Gregg's timeline is aggressive and calls for not only reviewing the school district's curriculum but coming up with a new strategic plan by January. In the immediate month, the district plans on convening a committee of stakeholders to talk about new programming at the district's high schools to help retain students.

The district will also look at its facility use and determine if it has any wasted space. During the most recent legislative session, lawmakers said Christina had too much underutilized space and the state and district were spending too much on maintenance and other costs because of that.

There is a sense of urgency to the plan rarely seen in Christina, school board members and staff said last week.

"Some of this is coming fast and furious and actually, I like that," said Elizabeth Paige, a Board of Education member. "I like that (Gregg is) being aggressive."

"This is the most excited I've been as a school board member and as a parent."

Darren Tyson, president of the Christina Education Association and a dean at Newark High School, said not only has Gregg put together a plan, but there's an air of excitement permeating the district this fall unlike anything he's felt.

Tyson has been with the district since 1996 and said he knows Christina is capable of doing more for its students.

"I was here when Christina was one of the top school districts in the country," Tyson said. "And I've seen the demise of Christina, as well. It's refreshing to see someone come forward with clear goals and a new direction for the district."k

Giving back to the community

Tyson isn't the only one who remembers Christina's glory days. Gregg attended McVey Elementary School, Gauger-Cobbs Middle School and graduated from Glasgow High School.

He says that's why he came back to Christina, leaving a job as the assistant superintendent of Penn-Delco School District in Delaware County, Pennsylvania.

"I want to be here," Gregg said, adding that "I guess in life, you want to give back to the community you got so much success from."

A superintendent with some staying power could be a good thing for Christina, which has seen several recent changes in leadership.

Christina’s previous superintendent, Freeman Williams, left the district in 2015 for medical reasons, and Robert Andrzejewski served as acting superintendent until Dec. 31, when Noreen LaSorsa took his place as interim administrator.

Before Williams was Marcia Lyles, who worked at Christina for three years before taking a job at a much larger city in New Jersey.

Though the school district has put together plans for increasing student achievement in the past, for the most part, they've fallen flat, said Gregg. The district's last strategic plan was released in 2014 and expires this year, and of the goals outlined, "none of them were met," Gregg said.

"For whatever reason, those things just didn't happen."

Christina's Board of Education, which has been criticized for failing to take responsibility for downward trends, claims to have been overwhelmed.

Conversations about priority schools, state takeovers and redistricting have distracted from the real issues, the school board's vice president Fred Polaski said, leaving little energy or appetite to focus on anything else.

The district's most recent strategic plan, which took an entire school year to put together, was basically "put on a shelf," he said.

"There was so much in it, you couldn't get it all done in the timeframes we hoped for," he said. "We never sat down and said 'OK, we can't do all of it. What can we do?'"

George Evans, who was recently elected school board president, hinted that the makeup of the school board itself has impeded progress. He talked about missed opportunities and failing to meet achievable goals, but didn't go into specifics.

He did say, however, that with the recent election of two new school board members, Meredith Griffin Jr. and Angela Mitchell, "I think there's more support than we've had in the past to get these initiatives done."

Griffin replaced Shirley Sutton-Saffer, who had been accused of making racial slurs but withstood several calls for her resignation before deciding not to run for a third term. Mitchell replaced Meg Mason, who in April abruptly resigned less than a year into her five-year term. She was previously a principal at Maclary Elementary School.

One vision, one voice

That's not to say that there aren't reservations about Gregg's plans.

John Young, another school board member, said he wants to make sure things don't move so quickly that the board isn't informed of all the changes.

He is worried new programs could be implemented unevenly or unfairly, pointing to the district's Middle School Honors Academy as an example. The program pulls top-performing students from the district's middle schools and sends them to Christina High School, leaving the rest of the students behind without anything to aspire to, he said.

"To me, we should have a Christina Middle School Honors Academy at each (middle school), contributing to the environment at those schools," he said adamantly. "All the other kids are leaving, and they have to stay."

New high school programs should avoid taking kids from their feeder schools, he said, positing that instead of forcing kids to choice into another school just for one class or program, they could be bused back and forth.

"Frankly, I think our geography is in our favor here," he said. "We're fairly compact."

Mary Schorse, president of Christina's PTA Council, said the district needs to begin acting as a single entity, not a collection of individual schools or programs where students don't all have access to the same opportunities.

"In this district, until I see otherwise, things just operate on a school-by-school basis," she said. "Things don't seem to come down from the district at all."

As a result, successful programs aren't always duplicated district-wide, she said. Though there are great things happening at some schools, those stories aren't always told and the community isn't aware of what's taking place at schools like Newark High School, where she has a student.

"Everyone thinks Christina is a horrible district, and it's not," she said. "They just don't know what's going on."

To that point, the district's new motto is "One District, One Vision, One Voice," Gregg said. He said turning Christina around will be a group effort, involving parents, principals, teachers, local businesses and more.

He envisions creating a variety of comprehensive programs across Christina's three high schools, though the same offerings may not be available at each one.

For example, Christina's music and theater programs may be consolidated in one building so the district can offer a higher-quality arts program and stem the tide of students that leave to go to Cab Calloway School of the Arts, Gregg said

"We have no options for our students along those lines," he said. "And I don't know why we couldn't."

Rebuilding community trust

One of the biggest challenges Christina may face when it comes to restoring the district to a place of prominence has little to do with academics.

Gregg said the district will have to work to regain the community's trust and overcome the perception that Christina hasn't been doing all it can to serve its Wilmington students.

"These students are our students no matter where they live," Gregg said, admitting "that may not be other people's perception."

To better connect with the community, the district will do everything it can to engage parents and other members of the public, he said. Christina will hold meet-and-greets and town halls, as well as form a parent advisory committee to meet with the superintendent on a regular basis.

Gregg said district administrators have been working with Gov. John Carney's office and the Delaware Department of Education's new Wilmington-based Innovation and Improvement Office, which is headed by Dorrell Green.

"Governor Carney has made clear that we must do better by our students in Wilmington, and we know that Christina's leaders share that goal," Green said in a statement. "We look forward to talking more about this issue in the coming weeks and months, and making real change to help kids in Wilmington succeed."

Though Green is a longtime Wilmington educator, a spokesperson for the Department of Education said he didn't have time in his schedule to talk about the new office's role or how it could assist Christina.

Carney, who toured Bancroft Elementary in Wilmington last week, said the Innovation office was formed specifically to help schools that weren't meeting state proficiency goals.

He also hinted at offering more support to low-income parents in the city of Wilmington.

Gregg was reluctant to detail conversations he's had with the governor's office but did mention the proposed creation of a consolidated early education center.

Right now, Christina's preschool program is spread out across multiple city sites, he said. There's interest from the governor's office in consolidating those locations into one, offering services to all children younger than 4 and offering training to parents.

"If we can get students on track for kindergarten, we can get them on track for third grade," Gregg said.

Gregg went on to say that, so far, there's been a lot of hope in Christina's new plan and district staff seems eager to turn things around.

"That's daunting," he said of the plan. "I don't want to lie about that. It's daunting because I don't want to dash anybody's hopes."

On the other side of the coin, "that's what I wanted the district to feel," he said, "that this is a new day. This is a new place for us. I think people can feel it."

"We just have to get it all done now."
