search_result.title: Are Uber, Lyft taking Delaware for a ride?
search_result.text:
Scott Goss

The News Journal

Delaware relies on Uber and Lyft to conduct background checks on their own drivers.

Screenings are supposed to weed out anyone convicted of major traffic violations and felonies.

State regulators have almost no idea who those drivers are.

When someone in Delaware gets a ride from the ride-sharing app Uber or its smaller competitor Lyft, there is no telling who is behind the wheel.

Drivers could have a history of violence that would not exclude them from picking up fares. Others may have been convicted of felonies after being hired, as was the case with an Uber driver recently charged in the beating of a University of Delaware student.

The same is also true of traditional taxi cabs and limousines, but those drivers are at least licensed by the state, a process that uses fingerprints to conduct a thorough background check using the FBI’s criminal database.

Drivers for app-based car services in Delaware are not subject to any permitting requirement beyond a basic driver’s license.

Instead, Delaware relies on Uber and Lyft to conduct background checks on their own drivers – screenings that are supposed to weed out anyone convicted of major traffic violations, along with felonies and other crimes related to violence, sexual offenses or child abuse.

State regulators have almost no idea who those drivers are and little ability to verify whether they have clean driving records and criminal histories.

STORY: Police - Ride-hailing driver choked Delaware student

STORY: Uber to pay up to $25 million fine

More and more people – predominately young adults – are now opting to hail an Uber or Lyft car rather than a taxi cab because of their lower cost and ease of use.

“These services are big with millennials who are plugged into the smartphone technology those companies use,” said Marcia Scott, a policy scientist with University of Delaware’s Institute for Public Administration.

Neither company will disclose how many riders they have in Delaware. Uber, by far the larger of the two, says it provides more than 5 million rides a day globally and has signed up "thousands" of drivers in Delaware.

Cabbies complain that ride-share drivers get more latitude, noting the state allows them to abide by fewer rules and regulations. That gives Uber and Lyft an unfair advantage and puts riders at risk, cabbies said.

“These companies are allowed to do whatever they want,” said Hamid Messari, owner of Blue Hans UD Taxi in Newark. “All we want is a level playing field, but right now the whole thing is a big mess.”

Critics argue the San Francisco-based businesses are nearly identical to their taxi counterparts. Uber and Lyft, they say, are simply using a new kind of dispatch system, while relying on loopholes and legal gray areas to avoid regulations that apply to their competitors.

“Taxi companies in Delaware are mostly mom-and-pop operations, while Uber and Lyft are huge companies,” Scott said. “It’s not hard to understand why the taxi companies might rail against those giants not being held to the same regulations.”

Falling through the cracks

At least one Delaware Uber driver with a history of violence already has slipped through a crack in the state's regulatory system.

Yolande Mcallister, a 32-year-old Uber driver from Christiana, picked up an intoxicated University of Delaware student sometime before 10 p.m. on May 17, according to court records. He then drove the 19-year-old man to George Read Hall, a dormitory off New London Road in Newark where police say Mcallister beat and strangled the student.

Both men got out of Mcallister's car at the dorm. Witnesses told police the Uber driver punched the student, knocking his head against the car's bumper. Mcallister choked the student before going back to his car to get his cell phone, witnesses said in court documents. The driver allegedly used his phone to make a video of himself kicking the student as the man lay on the ground.

Mcallister fled the scene. According to court documents, the officer who arrested Mcallister at his home said the driver can be heard boasting in the cell phone video, "I just had to knock this white boy out."

Police said Mcallister told them he had planned to post the video to Instagram.

Mcallister claimed the "extremely intoxicated" student had punched him in the back of the head during the trip, court records say. After arriving at his destination, the student – whose name is redacted from court records – got out of the car and fell to the ground, Mcallister told police. The driver says he laughed at the teen, prompting the student to punch Mcallister in the face through the open driver's side window.

None of the witnesses quoted in court documents said they saw the teen punch Mcallister.

Mcallister admitted to punching the student but denied choking or kicking him. The student was too intoxicated and disoriented to be interviewed, police said in court documents.

Mcallister is charged with third-degree assault, strangulation and disorderly conduct. He was released a day after his arrest on a $2,600 secured bond, according to the state Department of Correction.

He won't be picking up any more fares for Uber.

"He has been suspended from being able to access the Uber platform while we conduct our investigation and work with the authorities," Uber spokesman Craig Ewer said.

While Mcallister's Uber career began in February and lasted only a few months, court records show his troubles with the law in Delaware go back years.

He entered a first-offenders program in 2007 after being charged with offensive touching and terroristic threatening. However, that conviction was too old to show up on Uber's background checks, which only look back seven years.

Since then, Mcallister has twice been charged with offensive touching after allegedly strangling and pushing a family member. Those charges, which were later dismissed, also would not have shown up on Uber's background check, which only flags convictions.

In March – just weeks before the alleged assault at UD – Mcallister pleaded guilty to a felony conspiracy charge in connection to his role in the theft of nearly $8,000 worth of electronics and video games from Target in the Christiana Mall, his employer at the time. According to police, Mcallister and another employee operated a scheme in which one would bring merchandise the other's register where they would under-charge the items or simply waive them through.

That conviction should have excluded Mcallister from driving for Uber under rules set by both Uber and the Delaware Department of Transportation, which bars anyone found guilty of a felony from driving for a ride-sharing service.

But, Ewer said, that guilty plea came a month after Mcallister cleared Uber's background check –– and would not have been discovered by the company for at least another year.

DelDOT requires Uber to recheck its drivers' motor vehicle histories annually, but imposes no rule that forces the company to re-check drivers' criminal history after the initial approval. Even without that requirement, Ewer said Uber does re-check the criminal backgrounds of all its Delaware drivers once a year.

The follow-up background check might have caught Mcallister's felony conviction, but it would have come months too late for the UD student.

In defense of Uber, Ewer noted the felony would have been caught eventually. He also pointed out that Delaware law does not require taxi companies to conduct routine background checks after their drivers have been cleared for initial hire. A license to operate a cab is good for up to eight years.

"What happened in Newark is a regrettable incident and we stand ready to assist the authorities in any way we can," he said. "While no means of transportation will ever be 100 percent safe, Uber's technology creates accountability that improves safety before, during and after every single ride."

DelDOT officials declined repeated requests to comment on the lapse that allowed Mcallister to continue driving for Uber after he was found guilty of a felony. They also declined to say whether the incident would lead to any consequences for the company, or policy changes for the state.

"It is a police matter at this point," Delaware Secretary of Transportation Jennifer Cohan said via text message.

Left in the dust

Uber, the nation’s pre-eminent ride-sharing service currently valued at $62.5 billion, arrived in Delaware in 2014 and operates in most of New Castle County, Dover and Sussex County’s beach towns. Lyft says it has been offering rides in New Castle County since early 2015.

Yet, so far, the state has asserted only limited regulatory authority over those and other so-called “transportation network companies.”

Last summer, DelDOT signed a memorandum of understanding with Uber that set out the very first guidelines for it to legally operate in Delaware.

Gov. Jack Markell said at the time the deal "shows Delaware’s continued commitment to embracing the innovations of our new economy." Wilmington Mayor Dennis P. Williams went even further, spending $8,000 in taxpayer funds to rent four billboards welcoming Uber to the city.

Rules set out in DelDOT's deal with Uber included background check requirements, minimum insurance standards and prohibitions on drivers taking fares in taxi zones outside train stations and airports.

Those rules do not include requirements placed on the tax industry. Cab companies must get a business license, and drivers must complete a defensive driving course, obtain a special "Z" license –– enabling them to drive either a taxi, limo or bus –– get vehicles inspected twice a year and acquire a medallion.

Cab companies say those requirements can cost them up to $5,000 a year per vehicle, whereas Uber can utilize its entire fleet statewide for $5,000.

DelDOT set the minimum age for cab drivers and Uber drivers at 18, and eliminated anyone convicted of felony homicide, sexual offenses or crimes against a child.

STORY: Uber, Lyft halt Austin service after losing vote

STORY: Uber drivers in Dewey, other towns told to get license

Anyone convicted of driving under the influence, a hit-and-run offense, driving on a suspended license, attempting to flee a police officer, driving faster than 100 mph, reckless driving or bribing a public official also is barred from driving for a period of three to seven years, depending on the offense.

If Uber violates the Memorandum of Understanding it signed with the state, it could be fined or lose its permit to operate in Delaware.

But oversight and enforcement has been left largely to Uber.

Under its deal with DelDOT, Uber only has to turn over a list of up to 50 drivers once every three months to show that background checks and other requirements are being met for its staff. That’s a fraction of the thousands of Uber drivers the company says have given rides in Delaware.

DelDOT must ask for the list each quarter – something the agency has done only once in the last year.

“We’re about 30 or 45 days behind on that,” said Cohan, who took over as state transportation secretary in early 2015. “The letter to them either has gone out or is in the process of going out.”

After The News Journal asked about the status of those reports, DelDOT officials said last week they requested a second list of drivers from Uber.

Lyft has no deal in place with the state, which means that San Francisco-based company, valued at $5.5 billion, is not subject to any state regulatory oversight.

“We’ve been trying for the last month to reach to them,” Cohan said. “If they are operating in Delaware right now, they are doing it without legal authority.”

Lyft's website clearly shows the company's drivers are operating in New Castle County and a company spokeswoman confirmed its drivers have been working in the state since January 2015.

If DelDOT receives a complaint and can validate that a driver for Lyft is operating in Delaware, the department will issue a cease-and-desist order to the company and put the driver out of service, Cohan said.

Lyft declined repeated requests to comment on why it has not responded to DelDOT's communications.

In December, DelDOT proposed formal regulations for all ride-sharing services. One rule would have made all drivers get a business license. Another would have suspended any driver when a rider complains, pending a review.

But the agency put the brakes on that proposal two months later when Cohan shifted responsibility for overseeing those companies from the Division of Motor Vehicles to the Delaware Transit Corp. – better known as DART First State.

The move created a steep learning curve that DART officials are still climbing.

“We’re getting up to speed with it,” said John Sisson, who heads DART, an agency primarily responsible for managing the state’s bus and paratransit services.

“I don’t think there’s a perfect place for it, but it’s not a bad place,” he said. “It can make some sense.”

Yet questions about regulatory enforcement and whether drivers should be required to get business licenses, undergo a defensive driving course or abstain from smoking in their vehicles still remain unanswered.

Struggling to keep up

Even before the arrival of Uber and Lyft, DelDOT’s Office of Public Carrier Regulation – a two-person operation with additional responsibilities in the Division of Motor Vehicles – was struggling to keep up with the state’s taxi industry.

A 2013 report commissioned by the Delaware Center for Transportation found that a litany of flaws in the state’s regulatory oversight was directly responsible for creating “both service and safety issues” in Delaware’s taxi industry.

Cohan said she hoped to address some of those issues – along with the new challenges posed by Uber and Lyft – by moving the Office of Public Carrier Regulation to DART, and increasing its staffing to four employees.

“It’s something that was under consideration for at least two years,” she said. “DART is more directly involved with transit than DMV and we felt it was a more intelligent use of our resources.”

That combination of limited oversight and lack of organization may have created a perfect opportunity for Uber and Lyft to take root here and set their own rules of operation.

“Regulations have not caught up to these new companies, which cities and states across the country are just now grappling with,” UD's Scott said. “It’s a difficult and complicated topic, and I’m not sure there are any easy answers.”

Two sets of rules have been put forward by DelDOT and the General Assembly.

Neither would impose rules on Uber and Lyft that are currently in place to ensure passenger safety in taxis and limos, such as fingerprint background checks or two mandatory vehicle inspections per year.

Both proposals would require Uber, Lyft and other ride-sharing services to put a sticker in the vehicles' windows. DelDOT's proposal would require drivers obtain a business licenses, like cab companies do. The legislative measure would not require a business license.

But neither would address background checks.

Changing lanes

Delaware is not alone in scrambling to keep up with Uber and Lyft.

In just the last two years, roughly 30 states and cities have adopted new rules to govern the burgeoning ride-sharing industry – laws that consistently recognize those businesses as distinct from taxis.

Unlike traditional taxi and limo companies, Uber and Lyft do not employ drivers.

Instead, they simply offer a smartphone app that allows ride-seekers to connect with “independent contractors.”

The lack of overhead means those companies can undercut traditional taxis with much lower fares. Riders also get billed automatically through the app, eliminating the need for cash.

“There’s just no comparison,” said Don Sandusky, a 49-year-old self-described “technophile” from Landenberg, Pennsylvania.

The co-owner of a California-based sporting goods company, Sandusky said he has used Uber in Los Angeles, Nashville and New York City.

“Uber is cheaper than a cab and it’s like an instant pickup so you don’t have to hail a cab or wait around for one to show up,” he said. “And you’re riding in an Infiniti instead of some crappy cab.”

The apps also include rating systems in which riders can grade a driver’s performance, allowing the highest-rated drivers to qualify for the most fares.

“Some Uber drivers will have water or beverages for you to drink,” said Jon Klair, a 31-year-old waiter who uses Uber to get to work at Grain Craft Bar + Kitchen in Newark.

“They want their ratings to go up, while a cab driver probably doesn’t care,” he said. “Plus a cab might cost $60 while an Uber ride is, like $15.”

Uber and Lyft, which each get a cut of their drivers’ fares, argue the rules governing taxis should not apply to them because they offer a different business model based on new technology.

In addition to raising the ire of cabbies, the business practices of Uber and Lyft also have attracted more than 100 lawsuits in recent years, many centered on their classification of drivers as independent contractors, meaning they are not entitled to health care or other benefits that typically come with employment.

Lyft, for example, agreed to pay $12.5 million in January to settle a lawsuit brought by California drivers who sought to be recognized as employees. In April, Uber agreed to pay up to $100 million to settle a class-action suit brought by California and Massachusetts drivers who sought the same.

Much of the recent public and legal attention on those companies, however, has focused on background checks.

Eyes on the road

Both Uber and Lyft insist they conduct thorough background checks, even though no one from those companies actually meets with a driver in person before allowing them to accept rides.

The companies use third-party services that check names and Social Security numbers against criminal databases and department of motor vehicles files dating back seven years.

Uber agreed to pay at least $10 million in April to settle a suit brought by San Francisco and Los Angeles prosecutors. They alleged the company had misled passengers by advertising “industry-leading” driver screening practices.

The prosecutors claimed Uber failed to uncover the criminal records of 25 California drivers, including registered sex offenders and a convicted murder.

The company also agreed to pay $28.5 million in February to settle a separate case brought by riders, resulting in Uber renaming its “safe ride fee” to a “booking fee.”

Despite those lawsuits, Uber and Lyft have consistently resisted efforts by cities and states to require enhanced background checks.

Both companies, for instance, halted operations in Austin, Texas, this month after voters there defeated a ballot measure that would have overturned city regulations requiring them to conduct fingerprint-based background checks.

The companies spent at least $8.6 million to fight the Austin regulations, claiming fingerprint background checks are less effective than their current systems, biased against minorities and would ultimately hamper their ability to attract drivers by slowing the on-boarding process.

More jurisdictions are pushing the companies to impose stricter background checks in the wake of several high-profile incidents.

Most notably, Michigan Uber driver Jason Dalton is accused of killing six people during an all-night shooting spree in February. Dalton had no prior criminal history that would have excluded him from driving for the company.

New York City and Houston are the only cities that require ride-sharing companies to use fingerprinting. New York City may be too big of a market for the companies to risk losing, but Lyft opted to pull out of Houston in 2014 and Uber has threatened to follow.

It’s a fight Uber has won before by holding out from various cities in Florida, Ohio and Texas before those municipalities relented.

John Barrow, an occasional Uber user working to complete his doctorate in electrical engineering at the University of Delaware, said he’s not concerned about background checks.

But he does believe that Uber and Lyft are skirting rules in place for cabbies.

“The original intent of making a little cash by picking people up if you’re driving somewhere has gone by the wayside,” he said. “Now they’re just being cabs, essentially. I definitely think they’re getting away with something and should be a little more regulated.”

Klair, the Newark waiter and frequent Uber user, said he sees no point in changing the background check rules.

“The way [Uber] tracks the ride, the drop-off and destination, you’d have to be the dumbest criminal to kill or rape someone,” he said.

Forcing the issue and risk chasing Uber from Delaware, he said, isn’t worth it.

“It wouldn’t be cost efficient for me to take a taxi,” he added. “I’d have to restructure my entire day and routine because sometimes the bus only runs every hour and they don’t run late at night. Who would I get to take me home?”

STORY: Uber, Lyft, Google, Volvo, Ford form self-driving car lobby

STORY: More buiness travelers are ditching rental cars and turning to Uber and Lyft

New rules down the road

A bill scheduled for a committee hearing Wednesday, sponsored by state Sen. Bryan Townsend, D-Newark, who is running for the U.S. House, would require company stickers in the windows of ride-share vehicles, but would not require them to obtain a business license.

If that bill fails to pass, DelDOT says it will move forward with its proposed regulations that would include business licenses.

DelDOT believes that all ride-share drivers, each an independent contractor, are required to obtain a state business license, and municipal licenses for each town in which they operate. But Uber is now only required to tell drivers they "may" have to get business licenses.

And the state has no enforcement mechanism for ensuring they do get those licenses. The Department of Revenue does not track which licenses go to Uber drivers and few drivers have acquired business licenses in the six towns that require them.

Only one Uber driver, for instance, has purchased a business license in Rehoboth Beach, which charges a $325 annual fee.

“I think it would be naïve of us to think no other Uber drivers are operating here,” Rehoboth Beach police Chief Keith Banks said. “Right now, if we catch one without a license, they will be cited.”

Neither proposal, however, would force Uber and Lyft to provide any more information about their drivers’ criminal history or require them to follow other longstanding regulations on taxis and limousines.

“There are still some big questions that need to be answered about whether these businesses should be part of the free market or come under strict government control," said Marcia Scott, a policy scientist with University of Delaware’s Institute for Public Administration. "I think a lot more research needs to be done, quite frankly.”

search_result.title: NJ legal weed: Medical marijuana commission to hold first meeting
search_result.text:
TRENTON - The New Jersey Cannabis Regulatory Commission is finally holding its first meeting, nearly two years after it was established.

The CRC is set to meet at 2 p.m. Monday, where its five members will begin the process of overseeing legal weed, medical marijuana and the industries expected to grow around them.

The agenda for the meeting, held virtually, is light. CRC chairwoman Dianna Houneou and executive director Jeff Brown will make remarks. The panel will elect a vice chair. They will adopt an official logo and set a meeting schedule.

The five members of the CRC are:

Houneou, chair: Senior policy adviser to Gov. Phil Murphy, and a former policy director with the American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey, where she helped craft the 2019 proposed marijuana legalization bills that laid the groundwork for the laws now enacted.

Charles Barker: Projects specialist on U.S. Sen. Cory Booker's staff and member of the National Action Network, a civil rights organization.

Maria Del Cid: Policy and legislative services director at the New Jersey Department of Health.

Sam Delgado: Retired Verizon public affairs executive, U.S. Marine Corps veteran, founding board member of the New Jersey Statewide Hispanic Chamber of Commerce. (Nominated by Assembly Speaker Craig Coughlin.)

Krista Nash: Social worker and director for the Program for Returning Offenders with Mental Illness Safely Effectively (PROMISE) with the Delaware Valley chapter of Volunteers of America.

"This will be the first meeting of many as we put the values of equity and safety into practice in regulating this new industry,” Houenou said in a statement.

But the meeting itself is a sign that legal weed is a reality in New Jersey, but commissioners will be faced with a plethora of issues to address as the state takes its first steps into a new era.

Story continues below the gallery

Here are some of the major issues they'll need to address in order to hit the ground running:

Set a timeline for buying legal weed

This is the single-most burning question facing the CRC — pun fully intended — as New Jerseyans are currently allowed to possess small amounts of marijuana but have nowhere to actually buy it.

Under the legal weed laws, the CRC has six months to adopt its various rules and regulations before it can begin accepting applications for cannabis licenses — like dispensaries, cultivation centers, delivery companies.

RELATED: Who will be first to dispensaries — New Jersey or New York?

The best idea we have for a potential legal weed timeline comes from Gov. Phil Murphy, who appointed three of the five CRC members — as well as its executive director, Jeff Brown, a deputy health commissioner who headed up the New Jersey Medical Marijuana Program.

"I think there's a chance that you're six months from being able to buy it in one of our med dispensaries that are already up and running," Murphy said in a Vice interview last week. "My guess is it's longer than that for stand-up retail — maybe end of year, maybe early next year."

But in order for New Jersey medical marijuana dispensaries to begin selling to recreational customers, the CRC will have to accomplish another major task:

Fix the medical marijuana program

There are only 15 medical marijuana dispensaries across the state, tasked with serving over 100,000 registered patients. The New Jersey ratio of 7,400 patients per dispensary is among the highest of the 34 states with active medical marijuana programs.

The crunch has led to a supply-and-demand issue that has left patients empty-handed for years. While state law allows patients to purchase up to 3 ounces of medical marijuana, some dispensaries have placed strict limits on the most popular strains — limiting patients to as little as 1 half-ounce.

That's why it's vital the CRC devotes resources to making the New Jersey Medical Marijuana Program more affordable and accessible, said Amanda Hoffman, a medical marijuana patient and board member for the Coalition for Medical Marijuana New Jersey.

"We’ve been dealing with high prices and low inventory for the life of the program," Hoffman said. "Patients are not a priority for big business. They are here to make profits, not provide medicine. Patients and advocates laid the groundwork when no one cared about our difficult to treat, unprofitable medical conditions. Cannabis should be accessible and empowering for patients — not another burden for us."

Since 2018, it’s become far easier to get involved in the New Jersey Medical Marijuana Program — as a patent or a doctor — than in the eight years prior as new qualifying conditions were approved and registration fees were lowered.

The resulting boon — the patient population has increased more than eight-fold since Murphy took office in January 2018 — was supposed to coincide with a 2019 law to massively expand the program, with the Department of Health approving nearly two dozen new dispensaries.

But the DOH only issued six licenses before a lawsuit by applicants whose pitches were rejected derailed the process, after an injunction prevented the DOH from issuing any more licenses, a 15-month hiatus that only worsened the supply issues.

That court case has since been resolved, with an appellate court judge dismissing the majority of the complaints in the dispensary applicants’ lawsuit and removing the injunction. Now, the CRC is set to formally take over the New Jersey Medical Marijuana Program — it’s agenda item no. 4 for Monday’s meeting — and finally bring the wave of expansion patients have clamored for years.

And by making it easier to get medical marijuana, the CRC will be making it all the easier — and faster — for recreational customers to get their hands on New Jersey legal weed.

MORE: New Jersey legalized weed but forgot about its pot dealers. Now they want in.

Restore trust

This may be the most important task facing the CRC, though it’s not one regularly talked about.

If the CRC exclusively listens to cannabis industry leaders or political power brokers involved in the legal weed push, they'll only hear glowing reviews of what's to come: Thousands of jobs. Millions in tax revenue. Thousands of arrests slowed to a grinding halt.

But outside that inner circle, there’s a layer of skepticism that permeates any conversation about what legal weed will actually look like.

Log onto any social media discussion within the marijuana community, and you’ll see defeated posts from would-be entrepreneurs ruing the hundreds of thousands — if not millions — required to break into the business, even for a “microbusiness” license.

And there are hundreds of low-income medical marijuana patients, furious that growing one single cannabis plant in their backyard — the most cost-effective way to get medicine that otherwise costs over $400 per ounce — is still punishable by a five-year prison term.

Houenou, chair of the CRC, acknowledged this skepticism in a February interview with the USA TODAY NETWORK.

"People expect to be held back because of their prior entanglement in the criminal justice system," she said. "That's why we have to keep pushing reforms, not just in the cannabis context or even in criminal justice.

"We just have to look at people in a different way."

If the CRC is truly going to "ensure a fair and equitable adult-use and medical cannabis marketplace," as Murphy's office described the mission in a press release, the work needs to start at that first meeting.

Mike Davis has spent the last decade covering New Jersey local news, marijuana legalization, transportation and basically whatever else is going on at any given moment. Contact him at mdavis@gannettnj.com or @byMikeDavis on Twitter.

search_result.title: Michigan industrial hemp farmers hoping for booming new business
search_result.text:
LANSING – While many people are anxiously awaiting the start of Michigan's recreational market, a group of farmers and processors working with a different strain of the cannabis plant are celebrating their first harvest.

"We see an opportunity to truly scale the plant to produce CBD and the fibers from the hemp plant," said Dave Crabill, vice president of IHemp Michigan, an association of farmers, processors and manufacturers across the state.

The group met in Lansing on Monday to talk about the introduction of hemp into Michigan's agriculture industry.

Since the 2018 farm bill legalized hemp production, Michigan started a pilot program, registering and licensing 572 growers, who planned to plant 32,614 acres, and 423 processors. And after planting in the spring and summer, the farmers are in the midst of harvesting their first crop.

More:Michigan looking for people to try growing, processing hemp

More:Vaping illnesses: The difference between black market and medical marijuana dispensaries

The Michigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development doesn't know yet how many of those acres were actually planted, said Gina Allessandri, the state's industrial hemp program director, but should have a better idea by the end of the year what kind of yield the first crop will produce.

David Connor switched from farming blueberries in Paw Paw, in southwest Michigan, to 26 acres of industrial hemp. This year, he has gotten about 20,000 pounds of hemp that will be split between the hemp flower, which will be used for CBD products, and the hemp stalks that will be used in everything from building materials, textiles and paper materials.

"We're making some great headway in Michigan," he said. "And in 2020, we think it's going to be a huge year for Michigan."

The return on investment is promising, Connor said. An acre of corn in Michigan during 2018, for example, yielded about 153 bushels at $3.55 a bushel, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture, for a value of $543 per acre. Connor said the market value of the products from the CBD plant could be as high as $10,000 to $12,000 per acre.

"But this is an extremely labor-intensive process," he said, noting that since he's just finishing up his harvest, the market value is still an open question. "But we're very optimistic."

Hemp and marijuana are both cannabis plants, but hemp has much lower concentrations of tetrahydrocannabinol, or THC, the psychoactive component in cannabis that provides the high for users, than marijuana plants. Since 1970, all cannabis has been categorized as a controlled substance and, as such, considered illegal by the federal government.

The 2018 farm bill, however, legalized hemp and provides for regulating the growth of the plant. The fibers and stalks are used for a variety of purposes, including clothing, construction materials, paper, and plastic composites, while the seeds and flowers are used in health food and body care products containing cannabidiol, better known as CBD. The bill also allows for the transportation of hemp-based products across state lines as long as the THC level is below 0.3% level.

The risk involved for hemp farmers in Michigan is that any plant that tests above the 0.3% level has to be destroyed.

CBD-infused products derived from hemp range from tinctures, cream, candy and dog treats to water. CBD is touted, mostly anecdotally, as an ingredient that will do everything from provide relief from chronic pain and anxiety, make your skin smooth and silky, and calm skittish pets. The market for CBD products is expected to grow to $22 billion by 2022.

Casey Yosin, founder and CEO of Total Health Co., a CBD processing facility in Auburn Hills,, transitioned from the building industry to CBD production after a sports injury left him bedridden for six months. He researched the benefits of CBD and started using the plant.

"From my personal experience, I used CBD to heal," he said. "I figured it's something I can do to get out and help people."

An additional benefit for the hemp farmer, said Gary Schuler, founder and CEO of GTF LLC in Grand Rapids, is the ability to use the entire plant. His company dries and processes the hemp waste, which is then used in food products, animal feed, biodegradable plastic and building products.

"We're really helping decrease the carbon footprint," he said, because some of the petroleum-based plastics can be replaced by the biodegradable plastic made from hemp waste.

While waiting for final rules from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration, which will regulate CBD-infused food products, the state plans to continue the hemp program next year and will still register and license anyone who wants to get involved in the program. For more information on the state's industrial hemp program, click here.

The state's other emerging cannabis-based business — marijuana for adult recreational use — will begin after the state begins accepting business license applications on Nov. 1 and awarding licenses by the end of the year.

search_result.title: 2023 election replay: Ohio backs abortion measure, Democrats win ...
search_result.text:
Americans from coast to coast voted in Tuesday's off-year election, making their voices heard on controversial ballot measures, competitive governor's races and more.

Democrats won several victories Tuesday night, after Kentucky Gov. Andy Beshear was reelected, Ohio voters passed a ballot measure to protect abortion rights in the state and Democrats in Virginia won control of the state's Senate and House of Delegates.

But Republicans won in Mississippi, after Democratic candidate Brandon Presley conceded the state's governor race to Gov. Tate Reeves, the Republican incumbent.

Get our On Politics newsletter: Get the latest politics news from D.C. and around the nation

Catch up with all of USA TODAY's live coverage of Election Day 2023 here.

Sign-up for Your Vote: Text with the USA TODAY elections team.

Mississippi Republican Gov. Tate Reeves defeats Democratic challenger Brandon Presley

Republican Mississippi Gov. Tate Reeves won reelection on Tuesday, officially defeating Democratic challenger candidate Brandon Presley.

Reeves was favored in part because he – like other Southern Republicans – cast his opponent as a tool of national Democrats who support abortion rights and other policies rejected by conservatives from coast to coast.

"Joe Biden and his buddies have funded his campaign," Reeves said last week during his debate with Presley, which was marked by insults and interruptions.

– David Jackson

Another blow to Youngkin: Virginia Democrats win House majority

Democrats in Virginia took the House of Delegates majority back from Republicans Tuesday, dealing Gov. Glenn Youngkin a major setback.

Youngkin had rallied Republicans in the state behind a vision of a red Virginia and total Republican legislature. Democrats already put a stop to the governor's plans earlier on election night by holding their state Senate majority.

− Savannah Kuchar

Biden fares better than Youngkin on Virginia election night

President Joe Biden released his list of Virginia endorsements over the weekend, including 23 Democrats running for both the House of Delegates and state Senate. Each faced competitive match ups against Youngkin-backed Republicans.

By midnight Tuesday, 16 of those races had been called, and all but one were wins for Biden's picks.

− Savannah Kuchar

Presley concedes race, congratulates Reeves

Around 10:45 p.m. Tuesday, Democratic candidate Brandon Presley came to greet his supporters. He said he came up a little short on votes. Presley thanked his supporters and said the campaign was not about him.

"So many of you laid so much on the line to do this," he said.

Minutes before, Presley spoke with Gov. Tate Reeves and congratulated him on the win.

— Lici Beveridge

Democrats declare success in Virginia

Democrats Tuesday effectively won Virginia by holding on to their state Senate majority and officially stunting Gov. Glenn Youngkin and Republicans’ plans for a red Virginia.

Democrats had said they were “cautiously optimistic” heading into Election Day, particularly about their chances in the upper chamber. The deciding seat was called just before midnight Tuesday.

Their success means Youngkin will have an uphill battle with his proposed 15-week abortion limit, which Democrats in the state already blocked in January. Candidates on the left made abortion a top campaign message in 2023, and the final outcome could be a bellwether for 2024.

Heather Williams, interim president of the Democratic Legislative Campaign Committee, said Monday that Democrats would consider winning just one chamber “a huge win.”

“With this victory, Gov. Youngkin has been denied a governing trifecta and our newly elected majority stands ready to defend Virginia from Republican extremism,” Williams said in a statement Tuesday evening.

The House of Delegates majority has yet to be called, though Democrats currently lead in that chamber as well.

– Savannah Kuchar

Member of ‘Central Park Five’ elected to NYC council

Yusef Salaam, one of the "Central Park Five" who was exonerated for a 1989 attack on a jogger, won election Tuesday to be a member of the New York City Council. Salaam ran unopposed.

Then a New York-based real estate magnate, Donald Trump called for Salaam's execution, taking out a newspaper ad calling on New York state to re-institute the death penalty.

Salaam and four other Black and Latino men were imprisoned after being wrongfully convicted for the 1989 rape and beating of a white jogger in Central Park. DNA evidence exonerated Salaam and the other co-defendants.

– David Jackson

Mom of daughter killed in Robb Elementary School shooting loses Uvalde mayor race

Cody Smith won the Uvalde, Texas, mayoral race. He defeated Kimberly Mata-Rubio, whose 10-year-old daughter Lexi Rubio was killed during the shooting at Robb Elementary School last year.

Smith will succeed Mayor Don McLaughlin, who is stepping down after nearly 10 years leading the city to pursue a seat in the Texas House.

His campaign has called for “better communications among police agencies and mobilizing volunteers from the community to help those in need,” according to the New York Times.

− Sudiksha Kochi

Virginia Democrat makes history as state’s first transgender senator

Danica Roem became Virginia’s first, and the country’s second ever, openly transgender state senator. Roem won her race in northern Virginia by defeating Republican opponent Bill Woolf by about four points.

Mississippi is holding its first gubernatorial election since the overturning of a Jim Crow-era measure in Mississippi’s 1890 state constitution that targeted the power of Black voters.

The measure required any individual running for state office to win the majority of the popular vote and a majority of the state’s 122 House districts to be elected. If no candidate was able to do both, then the Mississippi House decided on the election outcome.

In 2020, voters repealed the system, instead requiring candidates to receive only a majority of the popular vote to get elected in the state.

"Now that it's just a popular vote, then the influence of the Black vote means more," said Charles V. Taylor Jr., the executive director of the Mississippi state conference of the NAACP.

Fearful of voter fraud? Officials aim to earn your trust in 2024

WASHINGTON − Ahead of another election cycle that is already shaping up to be contentious, federal and state election officials are in the midst of campaigns of their own to reassure wary voters about the integrity of casting their ballots.

They are recruiting poll workers, certifying voting machines and hosting lessons on how election systems work in community centers, classrooms and libraries.

The steps are needed, experts say, to restore voters' confidence in a system that, despite some flaws and outspoken election deniers, was mostly trustworthy and secure in the first place.

Those fraud claims, in part, gave rise to calls for major overhauls of election systems in some states led mostly by Republican lawmakers. Some, particularly voters of color, were already skeptical of a system with a history of discrimination that hasn't always been open to them. New laws to restrict access has fueled that mistrust, experts said.

Much of the work of assuring voters will fall to local elections officials, experts said. Americans have more trust in their local election systems, which they’re more familiar with, according to the nonpartisan Pew Research Center.

"People know their local election officials. They know when they go to city or town hall that they trust the people that work there,'' said Rob Rock, Rhode Island's deputy secretary of state. "It's really important to make sure that people understand the process.''

–Deborah Barfield Berry and Terry Collins
